case_vignette:
A 14-year-old male presenting to dermatology clinic with rosy cheeks and a history of easy sunburns and frequent respiratory infections. Physical examination demonstrates a prominent nose and ears, telangiectatic erythema in a malar distribution, and faint hypopigmentation on the cheeks.  Genetic testing is performed and reveals a BLM/RECQL3 mutation.  The patient is diagnosed with Bloom syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, a prominent nose and ears, and an increased risk of cancer.  The patient is advised to avoid excessive sun exposure and to use sunscreen regularly to prevent skin damage.
